Alice sells vegetables from a stall at the market and plans to use the money from this loan to buy more inventory, such as garlic and onions.  Alice hopes to earn enough money to be able to send all her children to college, and would also like to have her own house one day.

loans.use: To buy vegetables for re-sale

loans.name: Spola

texts.en:
Spola has owned a small food vendor store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Dodoma for 10 years. She belongs to Mkibizi "A" east group loan (Group code 2015). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 90. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Spola is 58 years old, married, and has seven children: ages 40, 39, 34, 32, 31, 30 and 20. She also cares for six additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria has been a poultry keeper and used clothes seller in the Kihesa neighborhood of Dodoma for 6 years. She belongs to Mkimbizi "A" group loan (Group code 2015). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 155. Every day she works for 9 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more poultry to increase her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Victoria is 30 years old, married, and has two children: ages 10 and 6. She also cares for three additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more poultry to increase her current stock

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en: Mrs. Phalla C. lives in Ou Kralang Duol village in Takeo province. She is employed in a garment factory. She is 36 years old and the mother of a child who is attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Noup Nuon, is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which he cultivates rice. With this plantation, he earns a little income to support his family. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Phalla C. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband so that he can be a motorcycle taxi driver and earn more income.  Her husband is shown on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Ruos' Group

texts.en:
This small loan is being requested by five borrowers, all of whom live in Domnak Ompel Commune in Phom Penh City. The group leader, Mrs. S., 28, has been a local cultivator for a long time. She now grows rice and vegetables, as well as raising pigs from home for a daily income. She is married with one child who attends school, whilst her husband works as a staff member for a company.

S.'s house is old; that is why S. is taking a loan for repairing her house. The loan will provide the family with a better standard of living.

The other borrowers in the loan group are as follows:

K., 44, who raises poultry for sale and is looking for a loan to buy chicks to raise;

C., 40, who sells Khmer noodles in the neighborhood and is asking for a loan to buy necessary ingredients for her business;

C., 41, who is a rice farmer and is applying for a loan to buy a motorcycle for her family's transportation; and

K., 35, who is a motorcycle taxi driver. He is asking for a loan to increase his wife's capital for growing mushrooms.

loans.use: To repair her old house

loans.name: Vanna's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna N. is a group leader of four, all of whom live in Kdol village in Takeo province. She is a rice seller and her husband, Mr. Meas Touch, is employed in a garment factory as an administrator. The couple have five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is a beautician who is hired by the local people for wedding ceremonies, parties, and so on. Their other three children are enrolled in the local school. Mrs. Vanna N. is applying for a loan to buy more cosmetic supplies to support her second child's beauty salon business.

One group member’s loan is end-of-term and the rest have monthly payment loans. The end-of-term (EoT) loan does not require payment on the principal loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor, as it allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetic supplies to support her second child's beauty business.

loans.name: Agripina

texts.en:
Agripina A. owns a sari-sari store (general store). She is 46 years old and has 3 children. She started her business in 1998 using her small savings of Php 2,000. Her business is doing so well. She uses her income to pay the tuition fee, books and other school requirements of her children. Aside from store, she goes gardening. She grows vegetables like squash, beans, tomatoes in her backyard. She and her husband water them everyday. Their harvest is what they use to buy their other needs.

She is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to attract customers to her store. Some of the loan, she will use to buy vegetables seeds for her small farm.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start and have their own business. They provide credit, trainings and insurance coverage to all their clients to help their small business grow.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for a general store

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorn S., 37, and her husband, Mr. Srong Chrouk, 40, live across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1990 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. The eldest, their daughter, attends university; one son is in primary school, and the youngest one is still too young to go to school. 

Sarorn has been a primary school teacher for 19 years and Srong has been a secondary school teacher for 20 years as well. Besides teaching, the couple has also been running a motorcycle and car cleaning shop in front of their house for 4 years. 

Sarorn doesn’t have enough materials to use for her business such as a pressure washer and a vacuum cleaner that why she is requesting her third loan of $1,000 to make the purchases. And she would also like to use a part of the loan to fill up the land around her house.

loans.use: To purchase a pressure washer, a vacuum cleaner for her motorbike and car cleaning business, and to fill up the land around  her house

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma has owned a small charcoal store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Dodoma for seven years. She belongs to the Namba Tatu East group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $75. Every day she works for 14 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Salma is 30 years old, married, and has three children: ages 13, 10 and 8. She also cares for six additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth owns a small food vendor store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Dodoma. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works for nine hours at her business.

She belongs to the Dodoma Road "F" West group loan. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business, increase her profit, and grow her business.

Janeth is 54 years old, married, and has four children: ages 30, 24, 18 and 16. She also cares for two additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sorn C., 63, and her husband Mr. Thorn Ven, also 63, live in a small village. The village sits across the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. The two were married in 1972 and they have two children, one son and one daughter. Their son is married and lives outside the family home. Their daughter works as a silk weaver.

Sorn has been a silk weaver since 1962. It’s a skill she learned from her sister. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then distributes them at the market in Phnom Penh.

Currently, Sorn has two looms - one for her and another for her daughter. Sorn is asking for a loan of $300 to purchase silk materials so she can continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.name: Oeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Oeun K. is a group leader of five people who all live in the Pech Entrea village in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare field in which to cultivate rice. On this plantation, she has a problem because this field has infertile soil, which badly affects her crop. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Mak Noum, is a construction worker. Mrs. Oeun K. is 30 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study.

All the members in this group loan are utilizing end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan's term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to make her crop more productive

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy K., 50, is married and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She and her husband are rice farmers who typically make US$4 per day. This couple has five children, four of whom are farmers and one who is a student. Soy K. would like to take out a loan to purchase fertilizers to increase her farm's production.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana M. is a 56-year-old widow. She has four children who are no longer in school.

Susana runs a fruit stand and sells coffee in a neighborhood market, a business she started in 1998.

Susana has requested a loan to help her business. She plans to use the money from this loan as rolling capital; she will buy more inventory for her stand such as apples, oranges, and mangoes.

loans.use: To buy fruit for resale.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida A. is a scrap buyer. She goes out to the nearby village and buys used bottles, papers, plastics, metals, iron roofs, and other scrap materials. She sells all of them to a main buyer, and she earns enough money for her family's needs. She is 53 years old and has 7 children. She started her business in 1998 using her small savings of Php 2,000. 

She is asking for a loan of Php 20,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more scrap materials to sell. She believes that her loan will bring her better profit because the more scrap materials she buys, the more income she gets.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start and have their own businesses. They not only provide credit but trainings and insurance coverage as well to help their clients' businesses to grow.

loans.use: To buy more scrap materials to re-sell

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokheng C., 46, and her husband Mr. Sokhan Sao, 49, were married in 1992. They have five children, two sons and three daughters. One of their daughters works selling Chinese noodles in Phnom Penh. The other four children still attend school. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh is the capital city of Cambodia.

Sokheng has been a silk weaver since she was seventeen years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman, who them takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a chef. He cooks for weddings and other ceremonies in his village and in the nearby village.

Sokheng does not have enough capital to purchase silk materials for her weaving business. Therefore, she is applying for her first loan of $150 to use so she can buy more silk weaving materials.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Lai

texts.en:
Mrs. Lai Y., 53, and her husband, Mr. Sophal Nou, 55, were married in 1976. They have seven children, three sons and four daughters. Two of their children attend school. Their five other children have found full-time employment. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh is the capital city of Cambodia.

Lai has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who travels to Phnom Penh to sell them at the market there. Her husband has been a farmer for seven years.

Lai is requesting a loan of $300 to fill in the land at the back of her house.

loans.use: To fill up the land at the back of her house.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en: Rin R. is 39 years old and resides with her husband in Siem Reap, Cambodia. She stays at home raising pigs and making rice wine. This business has been around for five years and she is able to make US$3 per day, while her husband sells wood and works as a farmer making US$3 per day as well. This couple has two school-aged children. Rin R. would like to take out a loan to purchase land so that her husband can expand his cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase land for farming

loans.name: Mrs. Thy Ly Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people living in the Phnum Lonteach village in the Takeo province comprise this village bank loan. They will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Thy L. is a 25-year-old village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare field in which to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Vath Sarin, is operating a poultry business. Since his poultry business is doing well, he wants to expand it. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Thy L. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks for breeding to add her husband’s business to earn more income. She has a child who is just 1 year old.

SeV. members in this group loans are utilizing end-of-term loans and the rest have monthL. payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for breeding

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: Khun T., 27, sells souvenirs, rice and foods in the Siem Reap province with her husband to earn a living. On average, they typically make about US$10 of profit per day. This couple has four children, two of whom are in school and two who are too young to attend. Khun T. would like to take out a loan to expand her souvenir store.

loans.use: Buy souvenirs for her store.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Lim S., 29, is married with two young children and resides with her husband in Siem Reap, Cambodia. She stays at home looking after her children and cooking for her family members. To earn a living, her husband, pictured here, is a mechanic, making US$9 per day. This couple would like to take out a loan to repair their leaking roof.

loans.use: To repair their leaking roof.

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila is the woman pictured sitting on the right, wearing the red khanga. Jamila has worked as a charcoal and "bites" seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for the past 10 years. She belongs to the Kondoa Group Loan (Group code 2026). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal, wheat flour and cooking oil for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. This will allow her to get more food for her family and to start to save money for future use.

Jamila is married. She has one child, who is 17 years old.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal, wheat flour and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Tru's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Trụ sinh năm 1957, (Mã số: 010102140001). Chị sống cùng chồng và 2 con với 2 cháu nhỏ. Chị chủ yếu ở nhà làm nông nghiệp.Chồng chị phụ giúp chị công việc gia đình và chăn nuôi. Con trai lớn đã đi làm, con dâu đi chợ bán hàng thức ăn, thu nhập 1 tháng là 4.000.000 VND.Chị có khả năng hoàn trả tốt hàng tuần. Chị rất nhiệt tình trong công việc nên nhóm đã bầu chị làm nhóm trưởng.Chu kì vay vốn lần này, chị vay mức: 5.886.000 VND để chăn nuôi và trồng rau. Nhóm vay gồm có:
 Ngô Thị D. sinh năm 1960, (Mã số: 010102140005). Chị mở cửa hàng bán tạp hóa nhỏ. Chị tham gia vay mức: 5.886.000 VND để lấy hàng về bán.
 Trần Thị Thuyên sinh năm 1953, ( Mã số: 010102140003). Chị làm thợ may. Chị tham gia vay mức 5.886.000 VND để kinh doanh cửa hàng may mặc và chăn nuôi thêm.
 Nguyễn Thị Vân sinh năm 1951, ( Mã số: 010102140002). Chị đi chợ buôn bán nhỏ và làm nông nghiệp.Chị tham gia vay mức vốn: 6.758.000 VND để lấy hàng về bán và chăn nuôi thêm
 Nguyễn Thị Ngữ sinh năm 1959, (Mã số: 010102140004). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp. Chị tham gia vay mức: 6.322.000 VND để đi chợ mua phế liệu.
texts.en:
Ms. Nguyễn Thị Trụ was born in 1957 (Member # 010102140001). She lives with her husband, 2 children and 2 grandchildren. She stays home and farms. Her husband assists her and also raises animals. Her son has a job and her daughter-in-law sells food, with total income of 230 USD per month. She is able to repay her loans weekly. She is very enthusiastic about her business, and therefore, the group selected her to be the leader. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 340 USD to invest in raising animals and vegetable farming. Her loan group consists of: Ms. Ngô Thị D., born in 1960 (Member # 010102140005). She has a small grocery store. She joined the fund to borrow 340 USD to purchase merchandise for her store; Ms. Trần Thị Thuyên, born in 1953 (Member # 010102140003). She is a tailor. She joined the fund to borrow 340 USD to invest in her tailor shop and also for raising animals; Ms. Nguyễn Thị Vân, born in 1951 (Member # 010102140002). She has a small grocery store and does farming. She joined the fund to borrow 390 USD to purchase merchandise to sell, and to raise animals Ms. Nguyễn Thị Ngữ, born in 1959 (Member # 010102140004). She does mainly farming. She joined the fund to borrow 365 USD to buy scraps .

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: business

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en: Phoeun C., age 52, is married with four children living at home in the Siem Reap province. She raises pigs and weaves roofs, typically making $2.50 USD each day. Her husband, Chan Choy, age 55, sells wood and typically makes about $1.50 USD each day. Phoeun C. would like a loan of $700 USD to purchase more pigs to breed and to purchase feed for the pigs.

loans.use: Raise pigs

loans.name: Mrs. Nhor Martt Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of 13 members, is located in the Kor village in the Takeo province. They plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Nhor M. has been selected by the members as the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land for cultivating rice. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because the field is infertile; thus, she decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Um Sam Arth, is a cook who is hired by people for wedding ceremonies, festival ceremonies, parties, and so on.

Mrs. Nhor M. is 51 years old and the mother of three children: one is a security guard, another stays at home to do housework, and the remaining one attends the local school. The husband of group member Mrs. Borin S. is present in the picture too.

Eleven members of this group loan are utilizing end-of-term loans while the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to make her crop more productive

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en: Phoeun C. is 48 years old and resides with her husband in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She sells rice noodles and grocery items to earn a living and is able to make US $2.00 every day. Her husband is a teacher and earns US $3.00 per day. This couple has one school-aged child. Mrs. Phoeun C. would like to take a loan to purchase a motorbike. The family will use the motorbike for transportation and to reduce the daily costs of their business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Mr. Phun U. lives in Tonle village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he grows rice. In addition to working on his farm, he is a palm juice collector. Even though he tries to work hard, he still earns less income than he needs to support his family. Thus, he has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding so he can earn more income. 

Mr. Phun U. is a 51-year-old widower and the father of four children. One of his children is employed in a garment factory. Two other children stay at home to help their father work and the remaining child is enrolled in school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Tem

texts.en: Tem Y., 45, is married and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She works in a grocery store, making about US$5 per day. Her husband is a village chief and earns US$20 per month. This couple has six children; three are in school and one is a construction worker. Tem Y. is asking for a loan to add more products to her grocery store to meet her clients' demands.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store.

loans.name: Mall

texts.en: Mall L., 27, makes US$2.50 each day selling fish in the Siem Reap province. She is married and has three children living at home to support. Her husband, Rom Huon, makes approximately US$5 every day as a construction worker. Mall L. would like a loan of US$900 to purchase a motorbike to transport her fish. This will help to reduce her daily transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Mayé Eugénie

texts.fr:
Née en 1965 à Abomey, A. Mayé Eugénie réside à Tokpota dans le 5e arrondissement de la capitale administrative et politique (Porto-Novo) du Bénin. Mère de deux (02) enfants tous scolarisés, Mayé Eugénie est vendeuse de divers, une activité qu’elle mène passionnément pour aider son mari à faire face aux charges familiales. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenu, Mayé Eugénie mène comme activité secondaire la vente des tissus qu’elle distribue à ses clients à domicile. Malgré la passion qu’elle a pour son activité Mayé Eugénie ne dispose pas d'assez de fonds pour mener à bien son activité et se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses charges. C'est pour ce fait, que Mayé Eugénie sollicite un crédit pour renforcer ses activités afin de faire face d’une part à ses différentes charges et d’autre part de se constituer une épargne.
 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1965 in Abomey, Ms. A. Mayé Eugénie resides in Tokpota in the fifth district of the administrative and political capital (Porto-Novo) of Bénin. She is the mother of two children, both in school, and she is a retailer of various goods, a business she operates with passion to assist her husband with family responsibilities. To diversify her income sources, she runs a secondary business selling fabrics that she distributes to customers in their homes. Despite the passion she has, Mayé Eugénie does not have the funds for carrying out her work and for making more earnings to meet her responsibilities. For this reason, she's requesting a loan to bolster her businesses, so as to address on the one hand her various expenses and, on the other hand, to build up her savings.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, peanut oil, soap, corn, and beans

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Him V., 34, is married and lives with three of her children in the Siem Reap province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$4 each day. Two of her children are in school and one is too young to attend. Him V. is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase fertilizer, fishing nets and a motorbike. With the fishing nets, her husband can go fishing sometimes; the family will use the motorbike for transportation to reduce their daily expenses. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets, fertilizer and a motorbike.

loans.name: Zahara

texts.en:
Zahara owns a small food vendor store in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma. She belongs to Mji mwema "A" group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, to get more food for her family and to pay school fees for her children.

Zahara is married and has three children: ages 24, 20 and 17.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda V. has a small "sari-sari" store (general store). She is 49 years old already and not yet married. She started her business in 2001 using the money that she has saved while working in Silver Smith store in Cebu City, host of the 12th ASEAN Summit held last January 2007. She has been a CEVI client for such a long time time already that she could no longer recall the exact date she joined the program. 

She is asking for a loan of Php 20,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional stocks to attract more customers. The loan will truly hep Esmeralda expand her business. In that way, she could support her siblings who are already married.

CEVI is a nonprofit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start and have their own business. They provide all their clients not only credit but trainings and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her store

loans.name: Mukarram

texts.ru: Хусейнова Мукаррам проживает в районе Гиссар. Живет в своей большой семье. Ей 38 лет и она имеет четверых детей. Образование среднее. Работает на рынке , торгует хлопковым маслом. Товар получает на масложирном комбинате города Душанбе и реализует в розницу. Ее товар пользуется большим спросом у населения и поэтому ее оборотная сумма не дает ей развивать бизнес. Теперь она решила получить кредит и при помощи чего она сможет развернуть бизнес.
texts.en:
Mukarram H. lives in the Gissar region. She lives with a large family. She is 38 years old and has four children. She has secondary education. Mukarram works on the market and sells cotton oil. She gets the merchandise from the factory in Dushanbe and sells it in retail. Her merchandise is very popular among the residents and this is why her working capital lets her expand the business. Right now she decided to apply for a loan to help her develop her business further.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock up the inventory

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab has owned a small food vendor store in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for 10 years. She belongs to Kondoa group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250. Every day she works for 9 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items (rice, cooking oil, etc.) for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, to get more food for her family, to save money for future use and to pay school fees for her children.

Zainab is 36 years old, married, and has three children: ages 15, 12 and 8. She also cares for one additional dependent.

loans.use: To buy more food items (rice, cooking oil, etc.) for her business.

loans.name: Hanch

texts.en: Hanch K., 39, is married and lives in the Siem Reap province with her husband. Since 2003, she has been selling vegetables and raising pigs to earn a living. She is able to make US$4 per day. Her husband is a rice farmer and makes US$5 a day. This couple has one school-aged child. Hanch K. would like to request a loan to purchase fertilizer and gas.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and gas.

loans.name: Alimatou

texts.fr:
Née en 1969 à DASSA,une commune du département des collines au Bénin, S. Alimatou réside à Tokpota dans le 5e arrondissement de la capitale administrative et politique-Porto Novo-du Bénin. Mère de quatre (04) enfants tous scolarisés, Alimatou est vendeuse de divers, une activité qu’elle mène passionnément pour aider son mari à faire face aux charges familiales. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenus Alimatou mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de tubercules d’ignames. Malgré la passion qu’elle a pour son activité Alimatou ne dispose pas d'assez de fonds pour mener à bien son activité et se faire plus de revenu à la hauteur de ses charges. Pour ce fait, Alimatou sollicite un crédit pour renforcer son activité afin de mieux développer ses activités d’une part et d'autre part de faire face à ses différentes charges. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1969 in DASSA, a community in Collines County, in Benin, Ms. S. Alimatou resides in Tokpota, in the 5th district of the administrative and political capital, Porto-Novo, of Benin. She is the mother of four children, all in school. And she is a retailer of various goods that is a business she operates with passion to assist her husband with family responsibilities.

To diversify her income sources, she runs a secondary business selling yam tubers. Despite the passion she has, Alimatou doesn't have the funds for carrying out her work and for earning more to meet her responsibilities. For this reason, she's requesting a loan to boost her work, so as to do better in developing her businesses on the one hand and, on the other hand, to cope with her various expenses.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, corn, beans, yams, and cassava flour (locally called "gari")

loans.name: Mirzomurod

texts.ru: Холов Мирзомурод житель Гиссарского района. Возраст 36 лет, женат и имеет пятерых детей. Уже восемь лет , как он занимается торговлей. Имеет небольшой магазинчик , где торгует напитками и продуктами питания. Планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы увеличить ассортимент и раскрутить свой бизнес . Это даст возможность получить больший доход. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mirzomurod K. is a resident of the Gissar region. He is 36 years old, married and has five children. He has been in the retail business for eight years already. He has a small store where he sells drinks and food. He plans to get a loan to increase the variety of goods and develop his business. This will give him an opportunity to make some profit. He will pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase commodity circulation

loans.name: Chhet

texts.en: Chhet Y., 48, is a widow who lives with her child in the Siem Reap province. She works as a farmer, making approximately US$2.50 each day. Her son is a pig breeder. Chhet Y. is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase rice to sell and to expand the livestock. She believes that these purchases will allow her to increase her income and be able to better support her large family.

loans.use: To purchase rice and raise pigs.

loans.name: Bich's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Bích sinh năm 1966, (Mã số:010102140032 ). Chị ở cùng chồng và 2 con. Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp và có đi chợ buôn bán nhỏ. Chồng chị phụ giúp chị bán hàng và đi chợ. Một con trai đi xuất khẩu lao động và một con trai đang học Cao đẳng. Thu nhập 1 tháng của gia đình chị là 4.000.000 VND. Chị là người rất nhiệt tình và tháo vát nên đã được cả nhóm bầu làm nhóm trưởng. Trong nhóm của chị còn có:
 Cao Thị Lưu sinh năm 1966, (Mã số:010102140012 ). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp và đi chợ buôn bán nhỏ. Chị tham gia vay mức vốn: 4.578.000 để đi chợ bán thịt.
 Trần Thị Lương sinh năm 1971, (Mã số: 010102140033 ). Chị tham gia vay vốn mức 4.578.000 VND để bán hàng ăn sang và chăn nuôi thêm.
 Nguyễn Thị Hà sinh năm 1971, (Mã số: 010102140035 ). Chị tham gia vay mức vốn 4.142.000 VND để đi chợ bán hàng thịt gà.
 Lại Thị Bẩy sinh năm 1959, (Mã số: 010102140034 ). Chị tham gia vay vốn mức 4.578.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn.

loans.use: business

loans.name: Trob

texts.en: Trob M., 50, lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$4 every day. Besides this activity, she also sells ice cream in her village. This couple has five children and all of them are farmers. Trob M. would like to request a loan to purchase ingredients and materials to make more ice cream to sell; they will use the rest of the loan to build a new house.

loans.use: Buy ingredients and build a new house.

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: Mme Afi A. est mariée et mère de huit (08) enfants. Elle est domiciliée à Tsévié. Elle exerce comme activités la vente d’emballage (sacs vides) et de charbon de bois. Les charges familiales se reposent sur elle seule, elle n’arrive pas à tout couvrir à travers les revenus tirés de l’exercice de son activité. Elle sollicite un crédit pour augmenter ses achats de sacs et de charbons. La réalisation de ce projet l’aidera à améliorer ses conditions de vie socio-économiques.
texts.en:
Ms. Afi A. is married and the mother of eight. She makes her home in Tsévié and works in selling wrappings (empty bags) and charcoal. Since family expenses fall upon her shoulders alone, she hasn't been able to cover them all with what she earns from her work. She's requesting a loan to increase her purchases of bags and of charcoal. The success of this project will help her to improve her socio-economic condition.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell wrapping material and charcoal

loans.name: Saphia

texts.en:
Saphia has been a meat, vegetable and charcoal seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for 12 years. She belongs to Kondoa group loan (Group code 2026).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175.Every day she works for 10 hours at her business.

 
She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more meat, vegetables, charcoal and etc for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, to get more food for her family and to pay school fees for her children.  


Saphia is 48 years old, married, and has three children: ages 13, 10 and 7.

loans.use: To buy more meat, vegetables, charcoal and etc for her business.

loans.name: Robiya

texts.ru: Шарипова Робия проживает в районе Гиссар. Разведена и имеет двоих детей. Возраст 33 года. Для того, чтобы обеспечивать детей ей приходится много работать. Имеет столик где торгует продуктами питания. За кредитом обратилась с целью пристроить навес, который спасет ее товар от солнца . Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Robiya S. lives in the Gissar region. She is divorced and has two children. She is 33 years old. She has a work a lot to support her children. She has a table where she sells food. She is asking for a loan to build a cover for her vendor space to protect her merchandise from the sun. She can pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a cover

loans.name: Bety

texts.en:
Bety G. has been a used clothes seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for 3 years. She belongs to the Mlamke group loan (Group code 2024).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70.  Every day she works for 6 hours at her business.  Bety is 40 years old, married, and has three children: ages 20,14, and 7. 
 
Bety is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more used clothes for her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and get more food for her family.

loans.use: To increase used clothes inventory.

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Nuon P., 40, is married with seven children. She lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She and her husband have a business catching fish and selling it at the market. They earn approximately US$4 per day. Four of their children are in school and the rest stay at home. This couple is asking for a loan to purchase fishing tools so that they can catch more fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools.

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Agé de 35 ans, Mr Kokou A. est un cultivateur et a, à sa charge, six (06) enfants. Il a bénéficié d’un premier crédit pour la culture de la banane qui a été dévastée par les précédentes inondations qu’a connu le Togo lors de la saison pluvieuse passée. Aujourd’hui il souhaite se lancer dans la culture du mais à grande échelle et sollicite pour cela un financement. Le financement de ce projet contribuera largement à changer positivement sa vie et celle de sa famille sur le plan social et économique.
texts.en:
Mr Kokou A., age 35, is a farmer who has 6 children to support. He obtained a first loan for his banana plantation that got destroyed by the floods that occurred in Togo during the latest wet season. He now wishes to start a large-scale corn growing business, which is why he is seeking a loan. Getting this loan will greatly contribute to changing his life, and those of his family, in a positive manner on the social and economic fronts.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Corn growing

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.fr:
Née vers 1964 à Porto-Novo,Capitale administrative du Bénin, H. Pierrette y demeure. Pierrette est mère de quatre enfants(4) dont trois (3) sont scolarisés. Tisserande de profession, Pierrette est aussi vendeuse de farine de manioc localement appelée gari et de glaces sucettes ; une activité qu’elle exerce pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenu,Pierrette vend également de charbon. Malgré ses efforts pour se faire plus de revenu, le rendement demeure toujours insuffisant. Pour ce fait, Pierrette sollicite un crédit  pour renforcer ses activités afin de mieux les développer et de faire face aux besoins de sa famille.
 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Pierrette H. was born circa 1964 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, where she lives now. She's the mother of 4 children, out of which 3 attend school. A trained weaver, Pierrette also sells tapioca (locally known as "gari") and ice pops to support her family. To diversify her income, she also sells charcoal. Despite her efforts to increase her income, her profits remain insufficient. Pierrette is therefore seeking a loan to strengthen her business, in order to bolster his activities and provide for her family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell charcoal and tapioca

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva E. is a "sari-sari" (general) store owner. She is 37 years old and has 2 children. Her husband, Presco E., is a farmer. They work together to support the needs of their family. She started her store in 1997 and her business is doing so well that she is planning to make it larger to store more goods for sale. All of her children are studying; she uses her income to pay the school fees like tuition, books, laboratory, and other school projects. She wants her children to graduate in college for them to have a better life when they are old.

Eva is asking a loan of PHP 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase additional stock for her store. In that way, she said, "I could have more customers. The loan will truly help me grow my business."

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start and have their own business. They not only provide credit to their clients but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To increase store inventory

loans.name: Luch

texts.en: Luch M., 21, is a true entrepreneur who has a business selling fish at the market to earn a living. She is able to make US$6 per day. Her husband, pictured here, is a fisherman who always catches and provides fish for his wife to sell at the market. This couple has two young children. Luch M. is asking for a loan to purchase more fish to sell, as currently there is a high demand from her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Nuch

texts.en: Nuch C., 45, is married and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She grows and sells rice and earns approximately US$3 per day. Her husband makes US$4 per day as a construction worker building houses. This couple has four children; three are in school and one is a construction worker. Nuch C. is asking for a loan to purchase land to expand her cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase land to expand her cultivation.

loans.name: Désiré

texts.fr:
A. Désiré est née vers 1978 à Porto-Novo, Capitale administrative du Bénin, dans le 5e  Arrondissement. A. Désiré est célibataire sans enfant. A. Désiré est gérant d’une cabine téléphonique et vend aussi de glaces sucettes. Pour diversifier ses activités et accroître ses  sources de revenu A. Désiré sollicite un crédit.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Désiré A. was born circa 1978 in the 5th arrondissement of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. He's unmarried and doesn't have children. He runs a phone booth and also sells ice pops. To diversify his business and sources of income, he's seeking a loan. Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell phone cards

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome M. has owned a small kiosk (minishop) and been a khanga seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for 6 years.  ( The khanga is a piece of brightly coloured rectangular cloth that is wrapped round the body.) She belongs to the Migombani group loan (Group code 2026).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250.  Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.  Salome is 46 years old, married, and has three children: ages 29, 25, and 4. She also cares for one additional dependent. 

Salome is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more khangas and other items for her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more store inventory.

loans.name: Dainess

texts.en:
Dainess has owned a small food vendor store in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for four years. She belongs to the Mlamke group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and to pay school fees for her children.

Dainess is married and has four children: ages 27, 23, 18 and 12.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply a hair dressing salon and purchase equipments

loans.name: Cheab

texts.en: Cheab P., 54, is married with six children and resides with her husband in the Siem Reap province. To earn a living, she grows corn and vegetables to sell at the market. On average, she makes about US$3 per day. Her husband is a farmer and earns US$4 per day. Cheab P. would like to take out a loan to purchase land so that her husband can expand his cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase land.

loans.name: Un's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is being requested by three borrowers, all of whom live in Chaom Chau Commune in Phnom Penh City. The group leader, Mrs. C., is 51 years old and the mother of six children; four of them are single and the other two are married. She presently makes a daily income of $5 per day from selling groceries out of her home. To help support the family's needs, her husband is a domestic construction foreman. C.'s investment is going smoothly and she has gained more income due to skilled communication in the village. To earn additional income, she is applying for a loan to increase stocks of groceries.

The other two borrowers are: S., who sells a few groceries from the family home and is looking for a loan to increase her business capital; and H., who is a widower father of three children. He works as an assistant to a village consultant and requests a loan to purchase furniture to decorate his house.

loans.use: To increase stock of groceries

loans.name: Hanch

texts.en: Hanch K. is 45 years old and resides with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$3.50 per day. This couple has three children; all of them are students. Hanch K. has requested a loan to purchase fertilizer and a water pump.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and a water pump.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To rent a workshop and buy sewing machines

loans.name: Léa

texts.fr:
Née vers 1963 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative du Bénin, A. Léa habite à Adjinan dans le 3e Arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Léa est mère de quatre enfants dont trois sont scolarisés. Léa est une vendeuse de glacières, une activité qu’elle exerce avec passion pour pouvoir subvenir à ses besoins. Pour accroitre ses sources de revenu, Léa vend aussi de tissus. Mais les revenus issus de ses activités ne lui permettent pas de répondre efficacement à ses besoins. Pour ce fait, Léa sollicite un crédit pour renforcer son capital d’une part et d’autre part constituer une épargne.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born around 1963 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Ms. A. Léa lives in Adjinan, in the 3rd district of Porto-Novo. She is the mother of four children, of whom three are in school. She sells coolers (insulated containers) that is a business she operates passionately in order to meet her needs. But the income from her work doesn't allow her to answer these needs effectively. Because of this, she's requesting a loan to one extent for bolstering her capital and to another for building up her savings.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy coolers and some cloth

loans.name: Shanti Singh

texts.en:
Mrs. Shanti Singh T. lives in a single-family home with her husband and their one son in Sainbu-Bhaishipati Lalitpur. Their son attends pre-primary school.

Mrs. T. and her husband Mr. Dhan Shyam T. have run their own grocery store for over five years. Before this, Mr. T. had tried hard to find suitable employment; when his efforts proved unsuccessful, he decided that he and his wife should open their own grocery business. They sell different types of grocery items at their store such as rice, maize, noodles, and a variety of snacks.

Mrs. T. is requesting a loan of 20,000 Npr to buy different varieties of grocery goods. Her primary aim is to provide a better education for her son.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods.

loans.name: Mamavi

texts.fr:
Mme Mamavi A. est marié et mère de deux (02) enfants. Agée de trente cinq (35) ans, elle s’est vite lancée dans la vente des produits de premières nécessités (riz, huiles, savons et autres). 
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de son activité et augmenter son chiffre d’affaires et ses bénéfices, elle sollicite un financement. Ce financement lui permettra de satisfaire la demande sans cesse croissante de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Ms. Mamavi A. is married and the mother of two children. She is 35 years old and got started immediately in selling essential goods (rice, oils, soaps, and more). Concerned about expanding her business and increasing her sales figures and profits, she's requesting financing, which will enable her to satisfy the ever-growing demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell basic goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To put a down payment on a motorcycle, buy a sidecar for the motorcycle, and to purchase fish for resale.

loans.name: Atu

texts.en:
Atu has been selling used clothes in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for three years. She belongs to Migombani group loan (Group code 2023). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $400. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business. 
 
She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can increase her inventory of used clothes and improve her business. She hopes that with the loan her profits will increase, she will be able to grow her business and save money for the future.  


Atu is 27 years old, married, and has two children; their ages are seven and four.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose has been a khanga and bites seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for five years. She belongs to Migombani group loan (Group code 2023).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works for 10 hours at her business.
 
She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more khanga, wheat flour and cooking oil for her business. She hopes that with the loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for the future and pay school fees for her children.  


Rose is 40 years old, married, and has three children aged 20, 18 and 16. She also cares for three additional dependants.

loans.use: To buy more khanga, wheat flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his fields and to buy fertilizers

loans.name: Shen

texts.en: Mr. Shen L. is a villager in Peaek Doung village in Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice to earn a living. On this plantation, he has a probL. because his field has infertile soil, which hurts his crop. In order to deal with this probL., he decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to help his field produce more crops. His wife, Mrs. Yin Deang, is a grocer. Mr. Shen L. is 42 years old and the father of two children; one is a grocer who helps his mother's business and the other attends the local school. He and his wife are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Elise

texts.fr:
Née en 1968 à Porto-Novo,Capitale Administrative du Bénin, O. Elise réside dans le 4e arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Elise est mariée et mère de quatre enfants dont deux scolarisés. Elise Transforme de maïs en pâte localement appelée « MAWE », une activité qui lui permet de faire face aux charges familiales. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenu, Elise mène comme activité secondaire la vente d’huile de palme qu’elle distribue à ses clients à domicile. Bien qu’elle mène quotidiennement cette activité elle . Elise ne dispose pas d'assez de fonds pour rentabiliser ses activités et se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses charges familiales. C'est pourquoi Elise sollicite un crédit pour renforcer ses activités. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1968 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Ms. O. Elise resides in the 4th district of Porto-Novo. She is married and the mother of four children, of whom two are in school. She takes corn and makes it into pâte, which is locally called "mawe" (cornmeal mash). This work enables her to cope with family expenses.

To diversify her sources of income, she runs a secondary business selling palm oil, which she distributes to customers in their homes. Although she works every day, she doesn't have enough funds for making her businesses profitable and for earning more to meet her family responsibilities. This is why she's requesting a loan for bolstering her businesses.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn

loans.name: Rama Shahi

texts.en:
Rama Shahi T. is a grocery shopkeeper in Sainbu-Bhaishepati, Lalitpur. She opened her grocery store to upgrade her family's standard of living. She opened her grocery store four years ago. She sells different types of grocery items in her grocery store. She feels proud to help her husband fulfill the needs of the family. She sells different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, noodles, biscuits etc in her shop. Now she is requesting Rs 25000.00 to buy different kinds of grocery items for her shop.

Mrs. Rama Shahi T. lives in a single-family house with her husband and two sons. Her husband works in a private office. Her older son is a house painter and her younger son is in grade 12.

loans.use: To buy grocery items

loans.name: Sreyneang

texts.en: Mrs. Sreyneang S. lives in Preaek Doung village in Kandal province. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Meng Sout, is a motor taxi driver who earns a little money to support his family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sreyneang S. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and to build a piggery, and to use the rest of the money to build a bathroom for her family. She is 29 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. She and her husband are presented in the picture.

loans.use: To buy piglets, to build a piggery, and to use the rest of the money to build a bathroom for her family

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr:
Agée de trente sept (37) ans, Mme Essi A. est une revendeuse de gâteaux et de beignets dans la localité de Gapé Centre. Elle est mère de trois (03) enfants tous scolarisables et entièrement à sa charge. Elle achetait en détail à crédit chez les bonnes femmes de sa localité les inputs entrant dans la production des gâteaux et beignets.  
Soucieuse de réussir, elle sollicite un financement pour s’approvisionner en farine de blé, en sac de sucre et en huile afin d’augmenter sa capacité de production. La réalisation de ce financement lui permettra d’atteindre ses objectifs socio-économiques.
texts.en:
Ms. Essi A., age 37, sells cakes and beignets (doughnuts or fritters) in the town of Gapé Centre. She is the mother of three children, all in school and entirely in her care. She was paying retail prices and buying on credit from the women in her town the ingredients for making cakes and beignets. Concerned about being successful, she is requesting financing to get supplies of flour, sacks of sugar, and oil in order to increase her production capacity. Obtaining this financing will enable her reach her socio-economic goals.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies of flour, sugar, and oil

loans.name: Sonu

texts.en:
Sonu M. lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in the Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural work. Thecho is also famous for wood carving work.

Mrs. Sonu M. lives in a single-family house. She has four members including herself in her family. Her husband, Mr. Sanu Kazi M., went to Saudi Arabia to work. She has two daughters. Her oldest daughter is in eighth grade and the youngest daughter is in third grade.

Mrs. Sonu M. is engaged in poultry farming. She buys young chickens and sells them to the dealers after 50 or 60 days. She already has completed her first loan from Kiva for the same business. Now she is requesting a Rs 20000.00 loan to buy more young chickens for her business.

She decided to work in this business to change her family's standard of living. She wants to provide a better education for both of her daughters.

loans.use: To buys young chickens

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Benkadi (toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 52 ans ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Gongebougou un des villages de la sous préfecture de Loulouni, cercle de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali (Sikasso).

Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de couscous , de beurre de karité et de noix de karité. Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux ans et sont à leur quatrième  prêt de groupe,  tous les précédents ont été  correctement remboursés. 

Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 4 sacs de 100 kg de sorgho pour en faire du couscous afin de le revendre et 2 sacs de 100 kg de noix de karité pour les revendre ou en faire du beurre de karité pour le revendre. Elles   s’approvisionnent à Gongebougou et  dans les localités avoisinantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Dallen, Nimbougou et Loulouni les jours de foire à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes  au comptant en détail et à crédit.

Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles ambitionnent être grossistes et avoir une charrette et un âne pour leur déplacement dans les différents marchés qu’elles fréquentent.
texts.en:
The four women of the Benkadi group (all married) have an average age of 52 and on average, 3 children. They live in traditional families in Gongebougou, one of the villages of the Sous-prefecture of Loulouni, Kadiolo circle, third administrative region of Mali (Sikasso).

They have various businesses, among others selling couscous, karité (shea) butter and karité nuts. They have worked with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for two years now and are on their fourth group loan, all preceding loans having been correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy 4 sacks of 100 kg of sorghum to use to make couscous which they will then sell, and 2 sacks of 100 kg of karité nuts to sell or to use in making karité (shea) butter to sell. They do their buying in Gongebougou and surrounding areas. The merchandise is sold at the market in Dallen, Nimbougou and Loulouni on market fair days to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash or on credit.

They each expect to make a monthly average profit of 10,500 F CFA of which part will be used for family needs and another part will be reinvested in their businesses. Their ambition is to be wholesalers and to have a donkey and cart to use as transport when going to the various markets where they sell their wares.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of karité nuts and cereals (sorghum for couscous)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and resell various items

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. Ny P. lives in Chhoer Teal village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate vegetables to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Yin Yun, is a fisherman. Although they try to work hard, they still earn little income to support their family. Mrs. Ny P. decided to ask for a loan to add her savings to buy timbers to build a house for her family.

She is a 50-year-old mother of seven children, two of whom are fishermen while others are farmers. Two of the children are enrolled in the local school and the remaining is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy timbers to build a house for her family.

loans.name: Shirjana

texts.en:
Shirjana M. is the tailor in the village of Thecho. She took six months of training for her tailoring work. She especially prefers to make the new style dresses such as the kurta-sulwar and blouse which are very popular among Nepalese girls and women. She is requesting Rs 10000.00 for her first loan to purchase raw materials for her tailoring work such as clothes, cutting machines etc.

Mrs. Shirjana M. lives in a single-family house with her husband and three sons. Her husband, Mr. Dev Bahadur, works in a carpet factory. Her older and middle sons are now studying in grades seven and four. Her younger son is just two years old.

She uses her income to fulfill the needs of her family. She wants to spend her income to provide a good education for all her sons.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her pineapples growing business

loans.name: Marry

texts.en:
Marry has been a banana seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for 12 years. She belongs to Donbosco group loan (Group code 2026).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $215. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.
 
She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bananas to sell and improve her business. She hopes that with this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business, get more food for her family, save money for the future, and pay school fees for her children.  

Marry is married and has five children aged 27, 21, 19, 15 and 11.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van R. is 63 years old and she lives in Dey Et Kos Poss village in Kandal province. She is a vegetable seller in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more vegetables to resell to earn more income. Mrs. Van R. is a widow with six children who are blacksmiths.

loans.use: Purchasing more vegetables to resell to earn more income.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace has owned a small food-vending store and been a clothes (vitenge) seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for four years. She belongs to Donbosco group loan (Group code 2027). Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.
 
She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more food items and vitenge for her business. She hopes that with the loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home, save money for the future and pay school fees for her children.  


Grace is 22 years old, married, and has two children, a four-year-old and a one-year-old.

loans.use: To buy more food items and vitenge.

loans.name: Eugénie

texts.fr:
Née en 1958 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative du Bénin, D. Eugénie réside dans le 4e arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. D. Eugénie est Mère de trois (03) enfants dont un (01) scolarisé.D. Eugénie est vendeuse de divers. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenu, D. Eugénie mène comme activité secondaire la vente d’ignames frites ; du haricot ; du riz préparé. Pour plus rentabiliser ses activités et se faire assez de revenus pouvant lui permettre d’envoyer ses enfants à l’école, Eugénie sollicite un crédit.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Eugénie D. was born in 1958 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, where she now lives, in the fourth arrondissement. Eugénie D. is the mother of three children, out of which one attends school. She's a reseller. To diversify her sources of income, she runs a secondary business selling fried yams, beans, and cooked rice. To increase her profits and her income enough to enable her to send her children to school, she's seeking a loan.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pasta, milk, sugar, soaps, bouillon cubes, rice, beans, and yams

loans.name: Janak Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Janak Maiya M. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives in a single-family home. There are five members including herself in her family. Her husband, Mr. Bhim Bahadur M., is a laborer in the housing construction business. Her older daughter works in an office. Her remaining two daughters are students in grades eight and seven, respectively.

Mrs. Janak Maiya M. makes traditional bangles from bronze metals. She gets orders from the dealers. All of her daughters also help her in this work.

Now Mrs. Janak Maiya M. is requesting her first loan of Rs. 10000.00 to buy raw materials such as bronze metals, a jigsaw and a cutting machine used in making the traditional bangles.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Suren

texts.en: Suren B. is married and has a 17-year-old daughter. She lives in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar (the capital city of Mongolia). Her husband is a truck driver. He spends a lot of his time on the road. In 2005, she started renting a small stall to sell apparel for young people. Although she was unemployed before this retail business, she decided to start her small business with 300,000 tugrig (Mongolian currency; $1=1600 tugrig) in capital. Since its inception, her business has successfully expanded; it now boasts a capital of 1,500,000 tugrig. In a typical month, her revenue averages about 1,000,000 tugrig; her profit is about 200,000 tugrig.  She is requesting a loan to buy more apparel to expand her retail business. She is a quiet yet very caring person.  She hopes that in the future her business will enable her to afford college tuition for her only daughter.

loans.use: To purchase more apparel

loans.name: Benkelema (Unity) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Benkelema (toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Gongebougou un des villages de la sous préfecture de Loulouni, cercle de Kadiolo,  3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali (Sikasso).

Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de riz, de couscous et de beurre  de karité.  Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatrième  prêt de groupe,  tous les précédents se sont bien dénoués. 

Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 3 sacs de 100 kg de riz paddy pour les décortiquer et  revendre, 4 sacs de 100 kg de sorgho pour en faire du couscous afin de le revendre et 2 sacs de 100 kg de noix de karité pour les revendre ou en faire du beurre de karité pour le revendre. Elles s’approvisionnent à Gongebougou et dans les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont vendues au comptant en détail et à crédit au marché de Dallen, Nimbougou et Loulouni les jours de foire à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 

Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four women of the Benkelema group (all married) have an average age of 32 and on average 2 children. They live in traditional families in Gongebougou, one of the villages of the Sous-prefecture of Loulouni, Kadiolo circle, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali (Sikasso).

They have various businesses, among others selling rice, couscous, and karité (shea) butter. They work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele, and they are on their fourth group loan, all preceding loans having been repaid correctly.

With this new loan, they intend to buy 3 sacks of 100 kg of paddy rice to hull and sell, 4 sacks of 100 kg of sorghum to make into couscous for sale, and 2 sacks of 100 kg of karité (shea) nuts to sell or to make into shea butter. They do their buying in Gongebougou and the surrounding area. The merchandise is sold for cash or on credit in the markets of Dallen, Nimbougou and Loulouni on market days, to a clientele composed of men and women.

They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 12,000 F CFA of which part will be used for family needs and the rest will be reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals (rice and sorghum) and  karité (shea) nuts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply her grocery store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his agoutis raising business

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Mrs. Seng K. lives in Preaek Takeo village in Kandal province. She is a cook who has been hired by other people. Her husband, Mr. Nao Thoul, is a hairdresser. Although they try to work hard, they still earn little income to support their household. Thus, Mrs. Seng K. decided to ask for a loan to fix her house to make it better for her family's living. She is 65 years old and the mother of six children, three of whom are waitresses in a coffee shop while the others are employed in a guest house. Her husband is presented on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To fix her house to make it better for her family's living.

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en: Oyunchimeg D. is a widow with a 13-year-old daughter. Her husband passed away several years ago. Now she lives and shares a small plot of land with her late husband's father and two brothers-in-law, in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar (the capital city of Mongolia). In 2007, with her brother, she created a small bakery. They launched their business in a small space rented from a local service center. They have two employees. They have a yearly examination from the District Office for Standards and Safety Control and they have successfully passed the examinations thus far.  They started the business by purchasing some necessary equipment with their own capital of 500,000 tugrig (Mongolian currency; $1=1,600 tugrig). Today, their capital has increased to 1,200,000 tugrig. She requests a loan to buy additional equipment and necessary ingredients. She says, "So far, I employ only two locals. In the future, as business expands, I hope to hire more local employees who are going through similar tough times."

loans.use: To buy equipment and ingredients.

loans.name: Dropati

texts.en:
Dropati M. is a resident of Thecho, Lalitpur, and lives with her husband and three daughters. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming.

Mrs. M. is a shopkeeper in Thecho and sells pots and utensils. All three of her daughters are studying in grade 9, 7 and 3 respectively. Mrs. M., along with her husband, Mahandra, opened her shop 10 years ago. They equally contribute their efforts in their shop because they have no other source of income, and their children also help them.

Mrs. M. is asking for a Rs 20000.00 loan to expand her shop by buying items like plates, steel glasses and hotpots to meet the increasing demand of customers. They want to strengthen the economic condition of their family by increasing their income.

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila has owned a small food vendor store and has been a used clothes seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for two years. She belongs to the Donbosco group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $170. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more used clothes and food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, to save money for future use and to pay school fees for her children.

Jamila is 24 years old, married, and has two children: ages 5 and 2.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes and food items

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen S., 25, is a mother who is caring for one child. She owns and runs a small wooden store in front of her house, where she sells little snack foods and some groceries for her neighborhood in the village. She is married to Sopheak, 28, who is a local goldsmith.

S. is working hard every day for income because she wants to make sure her one child receives the highest education. To make extra income, S. is looking for a $400 loan in order to use as capital in her business activities. The family lives in Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: To use as capital in her business activities

loans.name: Djidja (Courage) Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées, les quatre femmes du groupe Djidja ont en moyenne  32 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Gongebougou, un des villages de la sous préfecture de Loulouni, cercle de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali (Sikasso). 

Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la restauration, la vente de beurre de karité et de couscous.  Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire et le précédent a été remboursé sans difficulté. 

Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 1 sac de 100 kg de noix de karité pour en faire du beurre de karité, 2 sacs de 100 kg de sorgho pour en faire du couscous afin de le revendre et 1 sac de 100 kg d’haricots plus 1paquet de condiments alimentaires pour faire la restauration.
