Elles s’approvisionnent à Gongebougou, dans les localités avoisinantes et à Loulouni. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Dallen, Nimbougou et Loulouni les jours de foire à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.

Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 7.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités. Certaines femmes du groupe Djidja souhaitent être un jour  grossistes,  d’autres avoir de petits restaurants dans les différents marchés qu’elles fréquentent.
texts.en:
All married, the four women of the Djidja group have an average age of 32 and on average, 2 children. They live in traditional families in Gongebougou, one of the villages of the Sous-prefecture of Loulouni, Kadiolo circle, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali (Sikasso).

They have various businesses, among others selling cooked food, karité (shea) butter, and couscous. They work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele, and they are on their second group loan, the preceding loan having been repaid correctly.

With this new loan, they intend to buy 1 sack of 100 kg of karité (shea) nuts to make into shea butter, 2 sacks of 100 kg of sorghum to make into couscous for sale, and 1 sack of 100 kg of dried beans plus one package of condiments for their catering. They do their buying in Gongebougou and the surrounding area and at Loulouni. The merchandise is sold in the markets of Dallen, Nimbougou and Loulouni on market days, to a clientele composed of men and women.

They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 7,500 F CFA of which part will be used for family needs and the rest will be reinvested in their businesses. Some of the women of the Djidja group would like to become wholesalers one day; others hope to have little restaurants in the various markets where they do their selling.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of karité (shea) nuts, sorghum and dried beans

loans.name: Bijeshwori

texts.en:
Bijeshwori N. is a resident of Tangal, Lalitpur, and lives with her husband and one son. Tangal is a very busy shopping area of the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses. It is especially famous for brass, copper, and bronze pots and utensils in different varieties.

Both Mrs. N. and her husband are engaged in selling traditional stone statues. They started this work five years ago. They buy ready-made traditional statues and sell them in their shop. For this job business owners need lots of capital to invest in their shop.

Nowadays the demand for these traditional statues is increasing constantly. So to meet the demand of the customers, Mrs. N. is requesting a Rs 30000.00 loan to buy traditional stone statues to meet the demand of the customers. Their main targeted customers are foreigners.

loans.use: To buy traditional stone statues

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr:
Veuve et mère de cinq (05) enfants, Mme Akou A. s’est lancée dans la production et la vente de l’huile de palme depuis plus de quatre (04) ans. Elle n’opère que dans cette activité très répandue dans sa localité. 
Vaillante et aimant son métier, elle ne dispose pas d’assez de moyens financiers pour la production suffisante de l’huile de palme pour couvrir la demande du marché. Elle sollicite donc pour cela un financement afin d’augmenter sa capacité de production et augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Mrs. Akou A. is a widow and the mother of five children. Four years ago, she started producing and selling palm oil, a popular business in her village. This is her only money-making business. Courageous and loving her job, she lacks financial means to produce sufficient amount of palm oil to meet customer demand. She's therefore seeking a loan in order to bolster her production capacity and her profits.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To produce and sell palm oil

loans.name: Okhunbobo

texts.en:
D. Okhunbobo is the happily married father of two children. He leases eight hectares of land, all of which are planted with vegetables, as there is generally adequate irrigation all year round in the area. Thus, over the course of a year, the land can be planted on a rotational basis with potato, tomato, cucumber, wheat, and barley. Besides these, he has many fruit trees on his land. This rotational planting process preserves the richness of the land. Of course, it is also dependent on the weather.

For cultivating land this size, Okhunbobo requires additional funds to increase his expected yield. Last season, Okhunbobo faced considerable difficulties in terms of supplying his land with sufficient water. He has applied to IMON International for a loan in order to ensure a good yield of fruits and vegetables. This is Okhunbobo’s first loan and he is sure that his successful efforts will increase his income and improve his family’s welfare.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Binu

texts.en:
Miss Binu A., age 35, unmarried, is a tailor who works in the town of Patan. She opened her shop a year ago and specializes in making custom-fitted dresses and other clothing items for women as well as school uniforms for both boys and girls. Before starting her business, Miss A. took a six-month training course.

Miss. A. has applied for a 30,000 Npr loan to buy the raw materials she needs to make more clothing for her customers. She wants to use her increased income to upgrade her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring work.

loans.name: Udverte

texts.fr:
Née en 1970 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative, D. Udverte réside  dans le 3e arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Udverte est mère d’un seul (01) enfant scolarisé. Udverte a pour activité principale la vente de farine d’amidon appelée localement « Tapioca » et de charbon. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenu, Udverte vend aussi de l’huile de palme et de l’alcool local «Sodabi». Udverte sollicite un crédit  pour renforcer ses activités afin d’avoir plus de revenus. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Udverte D. lives in the third arrondissement of this city. She's the mother of one school-attending child. Her main business consists in selling cassava flour, known locally as tapioca, and charcoal. To diversify her sources of income, Udverte also sells palm oil and a local alcohol called "sodabi". She's seeking this loan to bolster her business, in order to increase her profits.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of cassava flour and charcoal

loans.name: Balikyewunya Group

texts.en:
Florence M. is an experienced businesswoman who runs a decorating business. She speaks at length about how to meet the needs of her various customers, explaining, for example, that if there is a celebration for someone who is Catholic, the colors will be different than if there is a celebration for someone who is Protestant. For each event that she decorates, she makes 40,000 to 50,000 Uganda shillings in profit.

Florence has been running her decorating business since 1988. When she was in school, she realized that she really enjoyed working with flowers and other decorations. After graduating from high school, she worked in various jobs before meeting some women who were doing decorating. She joined with them to learn the trade and has now been working in her florist shop in the city of Kampala for over 20 years. Florence has four employees who help her decorate at the various functions for which she is hired. They help her arrange all the materials.

She works with many media. She says that depending on the function, she might use dry, artificial, or real flowers. Besides flowers, she has many beautiful stands and papers that she uses to make everything look beautiful.

Florence says that loans are what makes her business possible, because she finds that while each customer wants individual decorations, they do not pay ahead of time; therefore, loans allow her to do her work at the high level of quality she expects of herself.

Florence has five children of her own that are still in school and five grandchildren that she supports. Although her husband is also working, paying school fees for 10 children is a difficult task. Florence is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ush to purchase artificial flowers and some large flower vases for upcoming events. Florence also keeps some pigs in her compound would like to use part of her loan to renovate the area where they are kept.

loans.use: Buying artificial flowers and large flower vases, and renovating the piggery.

loans.name: Nosir

texts.en:
H. Nosir has spent several years in the business of agriculture. He grows potatoes and wheat on his 3.5-hectare land. At the same time he raises cattle and sheep at his house. Nosir has a friendly family who always try to help each other. It is important to stress that he is a man whose responsibility is to provide for his family by giving them all that is necessary for their development.

Today Nosir needs a loan to provide technological assistance to his crops. He confidently awaits the approval of this loan knowing that it will be of great use in his business and that his family will greatly benefit. With part of the loan he will also purchase sheep to increase the head of his animals. The loan will greatly improve Nosir’s income and his family's living standards and for that he says a sincere thank you!

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.en:
A. Bakhtiyor is from Istaravshan, Tajikistan. He has been working for the past five years in agriculture and cattle. He is well known as a small producer in his community. His young son is the motivation for his many efforts and the reason why he is always looking for ways to work hard and get ahead.

He has applied to IMON International with the goal of obtaining a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for his crop. Bakhtiyor hopes the loan will allow him to increase his yield above and beyond what it was in previous years. As for his future plan, he wants all of his children to go to university and to get good jobs. You can be an important part of the growth of Bakhtiyor’s business.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Fotemogoban (La Grandeur Humaine Dépasse Tous Les Qualificatifs) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  femmes du groupe Fotemogoban sont toutes mariées avec en moyenne  46 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles à Gongebougou un des villages de la sous préfecture de Loulouni, cercle de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali (Sikasso).  

Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la restauration, la vente d’arachide et de couscous. Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatrième  prêt de groupe et tous les précédents se sont correctement dénoués.  

Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 2 sacs de 100 kg  de gousses d’arachide  pour les décortiquer, les griller et les revendre, 4 sacs de 100 kg de sorgho pour en faire du couscous afin de le revendre, 3 paquets de condiments alimentaires et 1 sacs de 100 kg de riz pour faire la restauration. Elles s’approvisionnent à Gongebougou, dans  les localités avoisinantes et à Loulouni. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Dallen, Nimbougou et Loulouni les jours de foire à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.

Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités
Certaines femmes du groupe Fotemogoban ambitionnent être un jour  grossistes,  d’autres avoir une charrette et un âne pour leur déplacement et  avoir de petits restaurants dans les différents marchés qu’elles fréquentent.
texts.en:
The four women of the Fotemogoban ("no words can describe the grandeur of the human being") group are all married and have an average age of 46 and on average, 2 children. They live in traditional families in Gongebougou, one of the villages of the Sous-prefecture of Loulouni, Kadiolo circle, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali (Sikasso).

They have various businesses, among others selling cooked food, peanuts, and couscous. They work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele, and they are on their fourth group loan, all preceding loans having been repaid correctly.

With this new loan, they intend to buy 2 sacks of 100 kg of peanuts to shell, roast, and sell, 4 sacks of 100 kg of sorghum to make into couscous for sale, and 3 packets of condiments and 1 sack of 100 kg of rice to cook and sell. They do their buying in Gongebougou and the surrounding area and in Loulouni. The merchandise is sold in the markets of Dallen, Nimbougou and Loulouni on market days, to a clientele composed of men and women

They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 13,000 F CFA of which part will be used for family needs and the rest will be reinvested in their businesses. Certain of the women of the Fotemogoban group hope one day to become wholesalers; others hope to have a wagon and donkey for their transport and to have little restaurants in the various markets where they go to sell their goods.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of peanuts, couscous, and cooked food

loans.name: Berdikul

texts.en:
H. Berdikul is 49 years old and lives with his wife and four children. His plans for his family are to improve their quality of life and to give all his children a better education.

Berdikul began working in the fields when he was 34 years old. It was his father who taught him how to work with the earth. He works in farming and also raises cattle, which he sells to bring in extra income. With this loan he will buy farming supplies so his harvest will be good and he can sell it for a good price in the market.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunita M. is a resident of Tangal. She lives in a single-family home with her husband, Mr. Shrawan Mistra, and their two sons. Her husband works in a garment factory, and both their sons are primary-school students.

Mrs. M. is engaged in weaving different types of woolen sweaters. She has five years of experience in this work. She makes different types of sweaters, customized to each order. She also sells sweaters at the market in Thamel, one of the most popular markets for tourists.

Mrs. M. is requesting a Rs 20000.00 loan to buy raw materials such as wool and needles for her work. She started her business in order to upgrade her family’s standard of living as well as to provide a good education for her sons.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her weaving work.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa F. is 45 years old. She is married and has six kids. Presently, two of them are pursuing education in the senior high school and the others are still in the basic school.

Theresa lives with her husband and children in a community called Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizeable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. However, quite an appreciable number are also involved in trading and other business activities. Theresa is in the business of palm oil production. She has been in business for eleven good years and is full of rich experiences.

She buys the palm nuts from the local farmers in her community; processes them in her house to produce the oil and sells at wholesale prices to her customers. Palm oil is a local vegetable oil produced from the food of the palm fruits which has been cooked, pounded, sieved and boiled for hours. The reddish substance (thus the oil) is skimmed off and reboiled to expel water content.

Theresa desires to use the loan to expand her business by buying the palm fruits in bulk to be able to supply to more customers. She believes the loan assistance would enable her to scale up production to serve a larger market and eventually, help improve her family finances. She is a member of a Trust Bank group called Temple Trust Group. Members of this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and support themselves in handling the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To buy palm fruits in bulk

loans.name: Khosiyat

texts.en:
J. Khosiyat is 54 years old and an admirable mother. She has shown a great, diligent spirit and enthusiasm for agricultural work and raising cattle. These activities have let her educate her children. She continues to strive toward providing well-being and education for her children and also toward being able to cover the expenses that her delicate health demands daily. As a result of this, her work has been very limited, and her profits have decreased notably. 

Khosiyat now wishes to increase the quality of her products with the purchase of fertilizers with the goal of obtaining a larger income to keep providing her children with education and improve their living conditions. She is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni, which she will use to make her dreams a reality.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina H. is 25 years old. She is not married. Regina lives with her younger sister in a rented apartment in a community called Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. However, quite an appreciable number are also involved in trading and other business activities.

Regina is a hairdresser by profession. She does both plaiting and perming. Regina says she graduated from the apprenticeship training four years ago and has since trained in hairdressing five young ladies who have started their own businesses. She has a small store close to the local market. Apart from hairdressing, Regina also sells plastic materials like bows, spoons, plates, etc. She displays them on a small table top in front of her salon.

She believes the loan assistance would enable her to buy hairdressing equipment, fashion accessories and artificial human hair and also pomades and other material she will need to serve her clients satisfactorily. She hopes to increase her income to enable her to save more to support her son’s education.

Regina is a member of the Happy Trust Bank group. Members of this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and support themselves in handling repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To buy hairdressing materials and fashion accessories

loans.name: Aline

texts.fr:
Née en 1977 à Dèkin dans la commune de DANGBO, L. Aline réside  dans le 3e arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative du Bénin. Aline est mère de trois (03) enfants dont deux (02) scolarisés. Aline a pour activité principale la couture. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenus, Aline vend aussi les fournitures de couture.Aline sollicite un crédit pour renforcer son activité afin d’avoir plus de revenus pour faire face d’une part à ses différentes charges et d’autre part pour constituer une épargne.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1977 in Dèkin in the city of Dangbo, Aline L. lives in the third arrondissement of the city of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. She's the mother of three children, out of which two attend school. Her main business is sewing. To diversify her sources of income, Aline also sells sewing supplies. She's seeking a loan to bolster her business and increase her profits, in order to pay for her expenses and start building some savings.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell sewing supplies

loans.name: Andokul

texts.en:
S. Andokul has dedicated himself to working in agriculture. He grows onions, watermelons, and wheat on his land. His family is made up of his wife and his three children whom he provides with the education that they deserve. It is important to point out that this gentleman has succeeded in this business and has been able to improve the conditions of his business thanks to his sacrifices and great efforts.

IMON International has been an important factor in his business's growth as it has given Andokul three loans which he has used to purchase supplies for his crops. Today he needs a loan to provide technological assistance to his crops which is why he confidently waits the approval of this loan knowing that it will be of great use in this business and that his family will greatly benefit. Andokul and his family sincerely thank you!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds, fertilizer, fuel, and lubricants

loans.name: Gita

texts.en:
Gita C. is a resident of Tangal. Tangal is located in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses; it's especially famous for brass, copper, and bronze pots and utensils of different varieties.

Mrs. C. has four members including herself in her family. She has two daughters. Her daughters are now studying. Mrs. C., together with her husband Mr. Tirtha Lal C., opened their grocery shop a year ago in their own house. They sell different types of grocery items in their shop such as rice, maize, paddy, noodles, and so on.

Now Mrs. C. is requesting an Rs. 20,000 loan to buy different types of grocery items for her business. She wants to use her income to provide better education to her daughters.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina T. is forty years old. She is married and has two little kids who are currently in the basic school. Faustina lives with her husband and children in a community called Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizeable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. However, a quite appreciable number of the women are involved in palm oil production. Faustina is one of the women who actively produce palm oil. She has been in business for five years. Her husband is a farmer.

She buys palm nuts from the local farmers in her community; processes them in her house to produce the oil and sells it at wholesale prices to her customers. Palm oil is a local vegetable oil produced from palm fruit which has been cooked, pounded, sieved and boiled for hours. The reddish substance (the oil) is skimmed off and reboiled to expel its water content. Faustina desires to use the loan to expand her business by buying palm fruit in bulk to be able to supply to more customers.

She believes the loan assistance will enable her to scale up production to serve a larger market and eventually, help improve her family finances. She is a member of a Trust Bank group called Temple Trust Group. Members of this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and support each other in handling repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To buy palm fruit in bulk

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia N. is thirty-three years old. She is married and has three little kids who are in basic school. Afia lives with her husband and children in a community called Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizeable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. However, a quite appreciable number of women are involved in palm oil production. Afia is one of these women who actively produce palm oil. She has been in business for five years. Her husband is a food crop farmer.

She buys palm nuts from the farmers in her community; processes them in her house to produce the oil and sells it at wholesale prices to her customers. Palm oil is a local vegetable oil produced from palm fruit which has been cooked, pounded, sieved and boiled for hours. The reddish substance (the oil) is skimmed off and reboiled to expel its water content. Afia desires to use the loan to expand her business by buying palm fruit in bulk to be able to supply to more customers.

She believes the loan assistance would enable her to scale up production to serve a larger market and eventually, help improve her family finances. She is a member of a Trust Bank group called Beauty Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and support each other in handling repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To procure palm fruit in bulk

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort T. is forty-nine years old. She is a married woman and has seven children. Five of them are currently pursuing education in junior and senior high schools. Comfort’s husband is a food crop farmer. Comfort and her family live in a family house at Nkwaateng in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Most of the inhabitants of Nkwaateng are either into farming or trade in farm products. Very few people run different types of businesses.

Comfort trades in second-hand textiles. She buys textile fabrics and all kinds of second-hand clothes including bedspreads, ladies’ wear and men’s wear, etc. from Kumasi, a nearby city, and sells them in the market square in her community. She says she also treks to nearby markets to sell. Comfort has been in this business for seven year now and wants a loan to increase her working capital so that she can buy textiles in bales.

She believes the loan assistance would enable her to reach out to other market centers and eventually, help improve her family finances. She is a member of a Trust Bank group called Courage Trust Group. Members of this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and support each other in handling repayment of the loan

loans.use: To buy bales of second-hand textiles

loans.name: Reshma

texts.en:
Reshma T. lives in Sainbu-Bhashipati Village. She lives with her husband and two daughters. Most of the people in this region are dependent on agriculture and farming.

Both Mrs. T. and her husband, Mr. Rabi T., are engaged in making handicrafts. They make different types of traditional sandals, which are made of thick cloth. Most of the people in Nepal use these types of sandals in kitchens. These types of sandals are also used in wedding ceremonies. They have four years of experience in this job. Mostly people use these sandals in the winter season.

They have opened small shop near their residential area. They sell all their products in that shop. Now Mrs. T. is requesting Rs 20,000 as a loan to buy raw materials for her work.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Kelengna (L'unité) Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kelengna (quatre veuves et quatre mariées) ont une moyenne d'âge de 37 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Santoro 1 de la ville de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté.

Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de riz et de poissons fumés. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité qu'elles mènent depuis plusieurs années. Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d'augmenter, le groupe Kelengna a décidé d'intégrer l'institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son cinquième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des sacs de riz et des cartons de poissons fumés à Mopti   pour les revendre au comptant à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 160.000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d'autres activités génératrices de revenus telle que l'achat et la vente de pagnes.
texts.en:
The women of the Kelengna ("Unity") group, four widows and four married women, have an average age of 37 and on average, 4 children. They live in big extended traditional families in the Santoro 1 neighborhood of the town of San (Ségou region, Republic of Mali). They met because of being neighbors or are related to one another.

They have almost the same business, selling rice and smoked fish. They are much sought-after in this business that they have been running for several years. So as to satisfy the needs of their ever-growing clientele, the Kelengna group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their fifth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been reimbursed correctly.

They intend to use this loan to buy sacks of rice and cartons of smoked fish in Mopti to retail on a cash basis in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). They each hope to make an average profit of 160.000 F CFA per loan cycle which will be used to repay the interest on the loan and support their extended families, investing the remainder in their businesses. Their ambition is to diversify their businesses by taking up other remunerative activities such as buying and selling lengths of African print cloth ("pagnes").

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of rice and smoked fish

loans.name: Victoire Emilienne

texts.fr:
Née en 1963 à Porto-Novo,S. Victoire Emilienne réside à Foun-Foun dans le 3e arrondissement de la capitale administrative et politique -Porto Novo- du Bénin. Victoire Emilienne est mère de deux (02) enfants tous scolarisés. Victoire Emilienne est vendeuse de chaussures, une activité qui lui permet d’aider son mari à faire face aux charges familiales. Victoire Emilienne vend aussi des sacs de sortie pour diversifier ses sources de revenu. Malgré la passion qu’elle a pour son activité Victoire Emilienne ne dispose pas d'assez de fonds pour mener bien son activité et se faire plus de revenus. Pour ce fait, Victoire Emilienne sollicite un crédit pour renforcer son activité afin de faire face d’une part à ses différentes charges.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1963 in Porto-Novo, Victoire Emilienne S. lives in Foun-Foun, in the third arrondissement of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. She's the mother of two children who both attend school. Victoire Emilienne is a shoe reseller, a business which enables her to help her husband with the family expenses. She also sells handbags to diversify her sources of income. In spite of her being very passionate about her business, Victoire Emilienne does not have enough working capital to have a successful business and turn a higher profit. To this end, she's seeking a loan to bolster her business in order to pay for her various expenses.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell shoes and handbags

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A. is forty-two years old. She is married and has three little kids who are in basic school. Comfort lives with her husband and children in a community called Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizeable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. However, a quite appreciable number of the women are involved in palm oil production. Comfort is one of these women who actively produce palm oil. She has been in business for five years. Her husband is a daily savings collector in the community.

Comfort buys palm nuts from the farmers in her community; processes them in her house to produce the oil and sells it at wholesale prices to her customers. Palm oil is a local vegetable oil produced from palm fruit which has been cooked, pounded, sieved and boiled for hours. The reddish substance (the oil) is skimmed off and reboiled to expel its water content. Comfort desires to use the loan to expand her business by buying palm fruit in bulk to be able to supply to more customers. She also trades in "kenkey," one the favorite local dishes, to supplement her income.

She believes the loan assistance would enable her to scale up production to serve larger market and eventually, help improve her family finances. She is a member of a Trust Bank group called Courage Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and support each other in handling repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To procure palm fruit in bulk

loans.name: Alikul

texts.en:
S. Alikul is engaged in farming business. He tills a 0.8 hectare piece of land that he inherited from his parents. Because of his farm, it is easy now for him to feed and clothe his family. Alikul says, "I am the head of the family, I need to work better for the future of my children”. Alikul needs a loan of 3000 Somoni. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer and seeds for his farm. The loan will truly give Alikul a better yield so that he can continue to support the needs of his family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Subadhara

texts.en:
Mrs. Subadhara B. lives in Chetapati, Kathmandu. Chetrapati is one of the busy districts of Kathmandu. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses like grocery stores. Mrs. Subadhara lives with her husband and sons. Her husband, Mr. Gyan Prasad Bhatttrai, is retired. Her sons are now working.

Mrs. Subadhara is engaged in pickle-making as a business. She makes different sorts of pickles. She took a month of training for pickles-making. Nepalese people love to eat pickles while having lunch and dinner. She sells her products door-to-door in the local market. Now she is requesting Rs 20,000 as a loan to buy various food materials used for pickle making.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making pickles

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is thirty-five years old. She is the mother of five kids and divorced. Her kids are schooling in primary and junior high schools. Elizabeth lives with her children in a family apartment in a community called Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizeable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. However, a quite appreciable number are also involved in trading and other business activities.

Elizabeth is a hairdresser by profession. She does both plaiting and perming. Elizabeth says she started her salon four years ago and has since trained eight young ladies in hairdressing; they have started their own businesses in other communities. She has a small salon and shop close to the local market where she works. Apart from hairdressing, Elizabeth also sells shoes, slippers, clothing materials, assorted pomades and cosmetics. She operates her salon from morning and switches over to the sale of goods in the evening through hawking.

She believes the loan assistance would enable to buy hairdressing equipment, fashion accessories and artificial hair and also pomades and other material she will need to serve her clients satisfactorily. She hopes to increase her income to enable her to save more to support her kids’ education. Elizabeth is a member of Kingdom Trust Bank group. Members in this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and support each other in handling repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To buy hairdressing materials and fashion accessories

loans.name: Tusooka Group (B)

texts.en:
Khamis runs a restaurant that has been in operation for eight years and employs three people. Khamis’ restaurant sells local foods such as posho, matoke, rice, beans, fish and various types of meat. Posho is a starchy product made from corn flour and water. Matoke is made from unripe bananas that are steamed wrapped in banana leaves. Both are staples in the Ugandan diet.

Khamis provides for her four children, ages 15, 13, 4, and 3 months. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant. She has already bought the necessary equipment like tables, chairs, bowls and utensils, so she is now able to restock her food storage with her loans. She will now buy things like flour, beans, salt, sugar and other items that can be bought in large quantities.

loans.use: To buy sacks of sugar, salt, flour, and beans

loans.name: Erdenebayar

texts.en:
Erdenebayar T. is a 32-year-old man who lives with his wife and a daughter in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He is originally from the Uvurkhangay province, where he used to run a small carpentry business with his father. In 2000, he moved to Ulaanbaatar with his family to pursue a new life.

In Ulaanbaatar, he launched a small shop for the wooden products that form gers (traditional Mongolian nomadic circular tents) in the Narantuul market, which is the largest outside marketplace in Ulaanbaatar. Since its inception, his business has expanded and currently employs four workers.

His firm brings raw wood from the Uvurkhangay province and manufactures the wooden products for tents in Ulaanbaatar. He receives direct requests from his customers thanks to his popularity and hard work; therefore, there is no need for him to rent a stall in the Narantuul market anymore.

Erdenebayar is a dedicated, hard-working and entrepreneurial man. He hopes to have a larger-scale production firm for wooden products. He says, "The first thing I am aiming for is to have my own plot of land and a place to live." He requests a loan to purchase more wood from the Uvurkhangay province.

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Loukouman

texts.fr:
Né le 22 avril 1961 à Abomey-Calavi, B. Loukouman réside dans le 3e arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative et politique-Porto Novo-du Bénin. Loukouman est père de quatre (04) enfants tous scolarisés. Loukouman est un technicien électronique et en a fait son activité principale. Cette activité lui procure de revenu qui l'aide à satisfaire les besoins de sa famille. L’électronique étant une activité qui nécessite de grands moyens, Loukouman sollicite un crédit pour acheter des équipements qui lui font défaut jusque là afin de rendre plus performant son atelier de travail.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born on April 22, 1961, in Abomey-Calavi, Loukouman B. lives in the third arrondissement of the city of Porto-Novo, the administrative and politic capital of Bénin. Loukouman is the father of four children who all attend school. He's an electronic technician, which is his main business, providing him with the income that helps him provide for his family. Electronics being a business which requires important means, Loukouman is seeking a loan to buy equipments he lacks, in order to make is workshop more performing.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy equipments for his electronics repair shop

loans.name: Esther Mpingu Group

texts.en:
Esther M. is 59 years of age. She is married with eight children aged between 11 and 25. She has a five-room house where she stays with her children. She also looks after additional family members.

Esther M. has three meals a day. Her greatest expense in a month is paying school fees for her children.

She works seven days a week and receives about five customers a day. She sells her hens on retail basis. She has done this business for 10 years now and the main challenge she has faced so far is that she has to sell seasonally when her hens are of age to sell.

Esther M. has worked with Kiva's partner MCDT for two years now. The reason she chose to work with MCDT is because it was easy for her to join. She will use this loan to buy chicken feed and to increase the number of hens she has in her stock. She looks forward to expanding her poultry business to a farm.

loans.use: Buy more hens

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. is thirty-seven years old. She is married and has five children, four boys and a girl. Currently, Ama says, two of her children have completed junior high school while the rest are still in the basic school and the senior high school. She lives with her family in a family house at Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana.  Nkwaateng is a farming as well as a commercial community.

Ama works hard to help her husband take care of the family. Her husband is a farmer. He cultivates maize, plantain and other foodstuffs in the community where they live. Ama sells cooked yam in the local market square. She procures the tubers of yam from the farmers in the surrounding villages. Ama has been in business for over four years now and is full of experience. She wants a loan to buy tubers of yam and other cooking ingredients in bulk so that she can serve more customers and increase her profit margin.

Ama is a member of the Kingdom Trust Bank group. Members of this group guarantee loans for each other and support the other members in repaying the loan.

loans.use: To buy tubers of yam.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To fix up her bar and to stock her shop

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina A. is fifty-one years old. She is a widow and the mother of three little kids who are in basic school. Augustina lives with her children in a family house in a community called Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizeable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. However, quite a large number of women are involved in palm oil production. Augustina is one of the women who actively produce palm oil. She has been in business for six years. 

She buys the palm nuts from the local farmers in her community; processes it in her house to produce the oil and sells at wholesale prices to her customers. Palm oil is a local vegetable oil produced from the food of the palm fruits. It has been cooked, pounded, sieved and boiled for hours. The reddish substance (the oil) is skimmed off and boiled again to expel water content. Augustina wants to use the loan to expand her business by buying the palm fruits in bulk. She will then be able to increase the number of customers she serves.  She owns a refrigerator and uses it for the sale of sachet water to support her family with additional income.

She believes the loan assistance would enable her to scale up production to serve a larger market and, eventually, help improve her family finances. She is a member of a Trust Bank group called Kingdom Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee loans for one another and support each other in repaying the loan.

loans.use: To procure palm fruits and sachet water in bulk.

loans.name: Ariunzaya

texts.en: Ariunzaya M., 26, lives with her husband and 6-year-old son in the Narantuul district of Ulaanbaatar (the capital city of Mongolia). Her family lives with her parents. Her parents are retired and her son is going to start school in the fall of this year. She works as a saleswoman at an apparel booth in the Narantuul market, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. She has gained significant experience in the local market as a saleswoman since she has been working there for several years. Her husband is a taxi driver. He recently used the profit from his business to pay off his car loan. She dreams of having a place for her family to live and raise their son on their own. She has requested a loan to buy clothes for her retail booth.

loans.use: To buy clothes for her retail booth.

loans.name: Kasujja Male Gorreti Group

texts.en:
Rose B. is forty-four years old and she is married with three children. She has a four room house with four people currently staying in it. She also takes care of two orphans who lost their parents. They have three meals a day and her greatest expense is food. 

Rose has a pharmacy and sells medicines to earn a living. She buys her drugs from a pharmacy in the city. Her business attracts about twenty customers a day.  She has been in this business for seven years now. Her greatest challenge is that many of her customers want to buy on credit and don’t want to pay her.

She has worked with MCDT for ten years now and she has worked with the K. M. Gorreti group for two and a half years. She will use this loan to increase her stock. Rose wants to educate her children until they complete their education, and then she would like to buy a plot of land and build rental houses.

loans.use: buy more medicines to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy used clothing, towels, etc. for resale

loans.name: Nantaba Aisha Group

texts.en:
N. Aisha is forty-three years old. She is married with six children between the ages of twenty-three and five. She lives with her family in a two room house.  She does not have access to piped water so she either buys water from others with piped water or she fetches from the stream. She has one meal a day and her greatest expenses are paying rent and feeding her family.

She sells Irish potatoes in the market where she rents a stall to display her potatoes. She works seven days a week.
She has run this business for over twenty years, receiving about twenty customers in a day. Her main challenge is that there are many others selling potatoes like her, so they have to share the customers.

N. Aisha has worked with MCDT for twelve years now and she has received twenty-three loans from MCDT. She
chose to work with MCDT because their services were available nearby. She will use this loan to increase her supply of potatoes. She wants to be able to pay fees for her children until they complete school.

loans.use: increase stock

loans.name: Nikanou (La Passion) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Nikanou sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d'âge de 54 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Lafiabougou de la ville de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté.

Elles exercent la même activité d'achat et de vente  de céréales notamment le riz et de gammes variées de condiments alimentaires. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d'augmenter, le groupe Nikanou a décidé d'intégrer  l'institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son septième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 

Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des tonnes de riz  et une quantité importante de condiments alimentaires (oignons, piment, laye, épice, soumbala et autres). Elles s'approvisionnent  auprès des paysans producteurs (en riz), des commerçants grossistes de la place et des forains venant de Sikasso (en condiments). Elles effectuent leurs ventes au comptant, en détail et à crédit à la maison et au marché de San à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de femmes. 

Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 300.000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition  l'ouverture d'un magasin de stockage à San.
texts.en:
The five women of the group Nikanou are all married and average 45 years of age and 5 children each. They live in large traditional extended families in the Lafiabougou district of the city of San (Ségou region, Republic of Mali). And they known one another through ties of community and kinship.

The group members work in the same business of buying and selling grain, notably rice and various ranges of condiments. The women are in high demand in this domain. In order to satisfy the needs of their continuously growing customer base, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their seventh solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding one have been correctly repaid.

The women intend to use this loan to buy tonnes of rice and a sizable quantity of condiments: onions, chili peppers, garlic, spices, soumbala (made of crushed fermented seeds or beans), and more. Supplies are gotten from rural producers (for the rice) and from wholesale merchants locally and from fair vendors from Sikasso (for the condiments). Sales are made at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, at the house and the San marketplace. The customers are composed of retailers and women.

They each hope to realize an average profit of 300,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to pay the loan interest, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business. The ambition of the group members is to open a supply store in San.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain and condiments

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 47-year-old Salma K. from Mwanza. She is married. Salma has been running a poultry ("kuku") business since 1992. Raising kuku is a popular microbusiness in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. "Kuku" means "chickens" in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital: You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. Salma works at the business for 9 hours a day, 7 days a week. She currently earns about $200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD in order to purchase more chicks to raise and resell. In the future, she plans to open another business. Salma thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania through microleasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed noncreditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase chicks to raise and resell

loans.name: Paul

texts.fr:
Né en 1973 à Porto-Novo, M. Paul réside dans le 3e arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative et politique-Porto Novo-du Bénin. M. Paul est père de trois (03) enfants tous scolarisés. M. Paul est un technicien en électronique et en a fait son activité principale. Cette activité lui procure de revenu l’aidant à gagner sa vie. L’électronique étant une activité qui nécessite de grands moyens, M. Paul ne dispose pas assez de fonds pouvant lui permettre de satisfaire le grand nombre de clients et se faire  plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses différentes charges. C’est donc pour rendre plus performant son atelier qu’il sollicite un crédit.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Porto-Novo, Mr. M. Paul resides in the 3rd district of the city of Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of Bénin. He is the father of three children, who are all in school. Paul is an electronics technician, which has become his principal work. This business of his brings in the revenues that help him to earn a living. Electronics being a business requiring significant means, he lacks enough funds for allowing him to satisfy the large number of customers and for earning enough to meet his various responsibilities. Thus, to make his workshop successful, he's requesting a loan.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electronic equipment and supplies

loans.name: Madina's Group

texts.en: Madina T. has a small home-restaurant business.  Madina started her business last year after her husband died.  She has four children that she is looking after.  The two who are at home helped her start her restaurant and the others who are in school helped over the holidays when they were at home.  Her restaurant has enjoyed great success so far because she sells her food out of her house and many people in her community know her very well, so she attracts many customers. She is requesting a loan to stock some supplies for her restaurant.  She will buy things like potatoes, flour, sugar, salt, and other things she can get in bulk. Madina hopes that someday she will be able to build a standalone restaurant.

loans.use: To buy flour, salt, sugar, potatoes, and other bulk food

loans.name: Annastazia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Annastazia T. from Mwanza. She is single. Annastazia has been running a shop since 2003, selling milk, cocoa, Blue Band and tea bags. She works at the business for 12 hours a day, 6 days a week, and is assisted by one employee.

Annastazia currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to buy mango juice, milk, Blue Band and cocoa. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Annastazia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy mango juice, milk, Blue Band, and cocoa

loans.name: Kyligonza  Florence Group

texts.en:
Florence K. is a 50 year old single mother of two, ages 18 and 21. She lives with her family in a one-room rental house with no running water or electricity. Her greatest expenses are rent and school fees for her children. 

Florence works six days per week selling charcoal from a spot she rents at the market. She sees about ten customers per day. Previously she sold potatoes, but she wasn’t able to make enough money doing so. She hasn’t had the same challenges with this business and she prays that it will continue this way. 

She has worked with MCDT for five years and has received ten loans. She chose MCDT because it was near her home. She will use this loan to increase her stock and looks forward to expanding her business.

loans.use: increase her stock

loans.name: Sabali (La Sagesse) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Sabali sont toutes mariées. La moyenne d'âge des femmes de ce groupe se situe autour de 50 ans  et elles ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Les membres du groupe Sabali vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Lafiabougou de la ville de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté.

Elles exercent la même activité de vente de bois de chauffe et d'ustensiles de cuisine (puisette, tamis etc.). Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. Pour satisfaire  le  besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d'augmenter, le groupe Sabali a eu une solution à ses problèmes en intégrant  l'institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son sixième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 

Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des chargements de camions en bois de chauffe dans les villages environnants et une quantité importante d'ustensiles de cuisine (puisette, tamis et autres) au marché de San avec les artisans. Le bois de chauffe est vendu au comptant et en détail à la maison. Quant aux ustensiles, ils sont vendus  au marché de San et à la maison à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes. 

Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 80.000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce et d'ouvrir une boutique.
texts.en:
The five women of the group Sabali are all married. Their average age is around 50, and they have on average 4 children. The group members live in large traditional extended families in the Lafiabougou district of the city of San (Ségou region, Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of community and kinship.

The group members work in the same business of selling firewood and kitchen utensils (ladles, sieves, etc.) and are in high demand in this domain. To satisfy the needs of their continuously growing customer base, they had an answer to their problems: join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their sixth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding one have been correctly repaid.

The group members intend to use this loan to buy truck-loads of firewood in surrounding villages and a sizable quantity of kitchen utensils (kettles, sieves, etc.) from artisans at the San marketplace. The firewood is sold retail in cash transactions at the house. As for the utensils, these are sold at the San marketplace and at the house to customers essentially composed of women.

The group members each hope to realize an average profit of 80,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to pay the loan interest, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business. Their ambition is to diversify their commerce and to open a shop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood and kitchen utensils

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora G. is a 32-year-old married woman with two children in elementary school. She lives with her family in a house in Nkwaateng in the eastern region of Ghana. Her husband is a food crop farmer. Most of the people in Nkwaateng work in farming or sell farm supplies. Very few people run other types of business.  

Dora trades in second hand textiles. She buys all types of textile fabrics -- including second hand clothing and bed spreads -- from Kumasi, a nearby city, and resells them at the market square in her community. She also treks to nearby markets to sell. To supplement her income, she prepares cold cocoa drinks and sells them with bread in the afternoons. 

She has been in the textile business for eight years and would like a loan to increase her working capital so that she can purchase textiles in bales.  She believes the loan assistance will enable her to reach out to other market centers and eventually help improve her family’s finances. She is a member of a Trust Bank group called ‘Adom’ (Grace) Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee for one another as social collateral for the loan and hold one another responsible for repayment.

loans.use: To buy bales of second hand textiles

loans.name: Kurusumu

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Kurusumu M., a 50-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is married and has four children, who are between the ages of 16 and 28 years old. She has been running a charcoal business since 2003.

Charcoal is used by many Tanzanians as fuel to cook their daily meals. Women cook food in small coal pots by arranging mkaa (charcoal), and then adding paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene in order to light them.

Because there is such a high demand for charcoal across the country, being a charcoal seller is quite lucrative. Kurusumu works at the business for 9 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by one employee. She currently earns about $200 USD per month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD in order to purchase more charcoal for resale. In the future, she plans to open another business. Kurusumu thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth S. is 42 years old. She is married and has three little kids who are in the basic school. Elizabeth lives with her husband and children in a community called Nkwaateng. Nkwaateng is in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. However, quite an appreciable number of women are involved in palm-oil production. Elizabeth is one of the women who actively produce palm oil. She has been in the business for five years. Her husband is a food-crop farmer.

She buys the palm nuts from the local farmers in her community, then processes them in her house to produce the oil, which she sells at wholesale prices to her customers. Palm oil is a local vegetable oil produced from the food of the palm fruits which is cooked, pounded, sieved and boiled for hours. The reddish substance (the oil) is skimmed off and reboiled to expel the water content. Elizabeth desires to use the loan to expand her business by buying the palm fruits in bulk to be able to supply to more customers. She also trades in kenkey, which is one of the favorite local dishes, to supplement her income.

She believes the loan assistance would enable her to scale up production to serve a larger market and, eventually, help improve her family finances. She is a member of a Trust Bank group called Ambassador Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and support each other in handling the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To procure palm fruits in bulk

loans.name: Allah Kan Dèmè (May God Assist Us) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Allah kan Dèmè est composé d’une veuve et de 3 femmes,  mariées dans des familles monogamiques avec en moyenne 45 ans et 4 enfants  dans le quartier Bananissabakoro de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali).  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et d’activités de petit commerce qui sont entre autres la vente d’encens, d’habits, de chaussures, des produits de beauté, de savon et des céréales (mil, fonio et riz).

Dans le souci de satisfaire leurs clientèles en nette croissance, elles décidèrent d’adhérer au programme crédit de  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 3ème prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.

Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter 4 complets d’habits brodés, 3 cartons de crème pour la peau, 2 cartons de parfums et 20 paires de chaussures. Elles se ravitaillent mensuellement en habits brodés, en chaussures et en produits de beauté au grand marché de Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Elles revendent en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et  dans une boutique située dans le quartier administratif de Ségou à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 

Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice  mensuel moyen de 39.500FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement du prêt et  la prise en charge  des besoins de la famille (nourritures, frais scolaires, santé etc.)  Leur objectif est d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The group Allah Kan Dèmè is composed of a widow and three married women who average 45 years of age and 4 children each. They live in monogamous families in the Bananissabakoro district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and know one another through ties of community, marriage, and small-scale commerce, which includes selling clothing, shoes, beauty products, soap, and grain (millet, fonio, and rice).

Concerned about satisfying their clearly-growing customer base, they decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding one have been correctly repaid.

This loan will be used to buy: four embroidered outfits, three boxes of skin cream, two boxes of perfume, and twenty pairs of shoes. The women resupply themselves monthly in outfits, shoes, and beauty products at the grand marketplace of Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). Sales are made at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, at the house, from going door-to-door, and in a shop located in the administrative district of Ségou. The customers are for the most part composed of women.

The women envision realizing an average monthly profit of 39,500 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan and to meet family needs (food, schooling costs, health, etc.) Their objective is to have a house for living in.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing (embroidered pagnes), shoes, and beauty products for resale

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel K. is forty-six years old. He is married and has three children who are currently in the basic school. Emmanuel lives with his family in a community called Nkwaateng in the Eastern Region of Ghana. A sizable number of the inhabitants are engaged in farming activities. An appreciable number of women are involved in palm oil production.  Emmanuel identified this as a business opportunity and bought three sets of milling and processing machines to start commercial palm nut processing in his community. 

He has one set of machines that pound the cooked palm nuts, and another one that extracts the oil from the palm nut fiber. His services have greatly reduced the drudgery that was previously associated with palm oil extraction and processing.

Since palm oil production is increasing in his community, he seeks a loan to enable him to buy additional milling and processing machines as well as accessories, in order to provide satisfactory and on-time services to his clients. He believes the loan will enable him to increase production and thus to serve a larger market. Eventually, the income will help improve his family's finances. 

Emmanuel is a member of a Trust Bank group called Temple Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee for one another, as social collateral, so as to access loans, and they support one another in handling the repayment of a loan.

loans.use: To procure milling machines and accessories.

loans.name: Nyètaa (Essor) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Nyètaa sont au nombre de quatre, toutes mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogamiques avec en moyenne 36 ans et 3 enfants  dans le quartier Bananissabakoro de Ségou  au bord du fleuve Niger (4ème région administrative de la république du Mali).

Voisines de quartier, elles font essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers.  Afin de renforcer leur fonds de commerce elles ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur  5ème prêt de groupe,  après avoir bien remboursé les prêts précédents. 

Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter 6 pièces de pagnes wax, 2 cartons de crème pour la peau, 1 carton de parfums, 20 sacs de charbon de bois, 2 chargements de  charrettes en bois de chauffe, 1 balle de friperie composée de chemises, pantalons, T-shirts, culottes et des draps. Elles se ravitaillent en pagnes wax et en produits de beauté à Bamako (capitale du Mali), en friperie, en charbon de bois et en bois de chauffe à la foire  de Ségou. Elles revendent au comptant, à crédit et en détail à domicile, dans une boutique au bord du goudron près du commissariat du 1er arrondissement de police et au grand marché de Ségou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 

Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  mensuel moyen de 42.500FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement du prêt et la satisfaction des besoins personnels.
texts.en:
